principles.title: Ensure that the user interface and rendered content are perceivable

guidelines.title: Provide access to alternative content
guidelines.summary: The user can choose to render any type of alternative content available (1.1.1) with an indicator that the alternative content is present (1.1.2) or a placeholder replacing the non-text content (1.1.3) . It's recommended that users can also choose at least one alternative, such as alt text, to be displayed by default (1.1.5). It's recommended that caption text or sign language alternative cannot obscure the video or the controls (1.1.4) and that the user can configure the text (1.1.6), size and position of media alternatives (1.1.7).

success_criteria.title: Render Alternative Content
success_criteria.description: The user can choose to render any type of recognized alternative content that is present for a content element.

notes.content: It is recommended that the user agent allow the user to choose whether the alternative content replaces or supplements the original content element.

success_criteria.title: Indicate Unrendered Alternative Content:
success_criteria.description: The user can specify that indicators be displayed along with rendered content when recognized unrendered alternative content is present.

success_criteria.title: Replace Non-Text Content
success_criteria.description: The user can request a placeholder that incorporates recognized text alternative content instead of recognized non-text content, until explicit user request to render the non-text content.

success_criteria.title: Facilitate Clear Display of Alternative Content for Time-based Media
success_criteria.description: For recognized on-screen alternative content for time-based media (e.g. captions, sign language video), the following are all true

notes.content: Depending on the screen area available, the display of the primary time-based media can need to be reduced in size to meet this requirement.

special_cases.title: Don't obscure controls
special_cases.description: Displaying time-based media alternatives doesn't obscure recognized controls for the primary time-based media.

special_cases.title: Don't obscure primary media
special_cases.description: The user can specify that displaying time-based media alternatives doesn't obscure the primary time-based media.

success_criteria.title: Provide Configurable Alternative Content Defaults
success_criteria.description: The user can specify which type(s) of alternative content to render by default for each type of non-text content, including time based media.

success_criteria.title: Use Configurable Text for Time-based Media Captions
success_criteria.description: For recognized on-screen alternative content for time-based media (e.g. captions, sign language video), the user can configure recognized text within time-based media alternatives (e.g. captions) in conformance with 1.4.1.

success_criteria.title: Allow Resize and Reposition of Time-based Media Alternatives
success_criteria.description: The user can configure recognized alternative content for time-based media (e.g. captions, sign language video) as follows

notes.content: Depending on the screen area available, the display of the primary time-based media can need to be reduced in size or hidden to meet this requirement.
Implementation can involve displaying alternative content for time-based media in a separate viewport, but this is not required.

special_cases.title: Resize
special_cases.description: The user can resize alternative content for time-based media to at least 50% of the size of the top-level viewports.

special_cases.title: Reposition
special_cases.description: The user can reposition alternative content for time-based media to two or more of the following: above, below, to the right, to the left, and overlapping the primary time-based media.

guidelines.title: Repair missing content
guidelines.summary: The user can request useful alternative content when the author fails to provide it. For example, showing metadata in place of missing or empty (1.2.1) alt text. The user can ask the browser to predict missing structural information, such as field labels, table headings or section headings (1.2.2).

success_criteria.title: Support Repair by Assistive Technologies
success_criteria.description: If text alternatives for non-text content are missing or empty, the user agent doesn't attempt to repair the text alternatives by substituting text values that are also available to assistive technologies (e.g. image file name)

guidelines.title: Provide highlighting for selection, keyboard focus, enabled elements, visited links
guidelines.summary: The user can visually distinguish between selected, focused, and enabled items; and recently visited links (1.3.1); with a choice of highlighting options that at least include foreground and background colors, and border color and thickness (1.3.2).

success_criteria.title: Distinguishable Highlighting
success_criteria.description: The user can have the following types of content uniquely highlighted, overriding any values specified by the author:

special_cases.title: Active keyboard focus (indicated by focus cursors and/or text cursors)

success_criteria.title: Highlighting Options
success_criteria.description: The user can set all of the following characteristics of selection highlighting, overriding any values specified by the author:

success_criteria.title: Highlighting Active Keyboard Focus
success_criteria.description: The user can set all of the following characteristics of active keyboard focus highlighting, overriding any values specified by the author:

success_criteria.title: Distinguishing Enabled Elements
success_criteria.description: The user can set all of the following characteristics of enabled element highlighting, overriding any values specified by the author:

success_criteria.title: Distinguishing Enabled Elements
success_criteria.description: The user can set all of the following characteristics for visited links and separately for unvisited links, overriding any values specified by the author:

guidelines.title: Provide text configuration
guidelines.summary: The user can set text scale, color, style, line spacing, and font family globally (1.4.1, Level A). It is recommended that the user agent implement the user-selected text configuration settings of the platform (1.4.5 Level AA), users set text size, color, line spacing, text style and font family for element types (1.4.2, Level AA); set character spacing, justification and margin sizes globally (1.4.3, Level AA); set capitalization, hyphenation, and borders globally (1.4.6, Level AAA); and print configured and reflowed text (1.4.4 Level AA).

notes.content: The success criteria in guideline 1.4 can be met through user stylesheets. For platforms without user stylesheets, text configuration needs to be provided to users through the user agent's main user interface or via an add-on.

Users have varying needs for text size and spacing. Therefore, it’s recommended that user agents provide a wider range of values, and a greater number of increments, to allow the user to adjust the view for their current task.

success_criteria.title: Basic text formatting (Globally)
success_criteria.description: The user can globally set all of the following characteristics of visually rendered text content:

special_cases.title: Text scale with preserved size distinctions (e.g. keeping headings proportional to main font)
Text color and background color, choosing from all platform color options
Font family, choosing from all installed fonts
Line spacing, choosing from a range with at least three values up to at least 2 times the default
Text style, choosing to turn on/off underline, italic, bold

success_criteria.title: Basic text formatting (by Element)
success_criteria.description: The user can set all of the following characteristics of visually rendered text content for text element types including at least headings, input fields, and links:

special_cases.title: Text color and background color, choosing from all platform color options
Font family, choosing from at least all installed fonts
Line spacing, choosing from a range with at least three values up to at least 2 times the default
Text style, choosing to turn on/off underline, italic, bold

success_criteria.title: Blocks of text (Globally)
success_criteria.description: The user can globally set all of the following characteristics of visually rendered blocks of text:

special_cases.title: Character spacing, choosing from a range with at least 5 values
Justification (left or right, including turning off full justification)

success_criteria.title: Configured and Reflowed Text Printing
success_criteria.description: The user can print the rendered content, and the following are all true:

special_cases.title: any visual, non-time-based, rendered content can be printed
the user can choose between available printing devices
the user can have content printed as it is rendered on screen, reflecting any user scaling, highlighting, and other modifications
the user can have printed content reflow as if the top-level viewports had been resized to match the horizontal dimension of the printing device's printable area

success_criteria.title: Default to platform text settings
success_criteria.description: The user can specify that platform text settings be used as the default values for text configuration.

success_criteria.title: Advanced text formatting
success_criteria.description: The user can globally set all of the following characteristics of visually rendered blocks of text:

notes.content: This success criterion does not apply to text entered as all caps. Content authors are encouraged to use styles instead of typing text as all caps.

special_cases.title: Capitalization (overriding upper case and small caps style)
Word spacing (choosing from a range of at least 5 values)

guidelines.title: Provide volume configuration
guidelines.summary: The user can adjust the volume of each audio track relative to the global volume level (1.5.1).

success_criteria.title: Global Volume
success_criteria.description: The user can adjust the volume of each audio track independently of other tracks, relative to the global volume level set through operating environment mechanisms.

guidelines.title: Provide synthesized speech configuration
guidelines.summary: If synthesized speech is produced, the user can specify speech rate, volume, and voice (1.6.1, Level A), pitch and pitch range (1.6.2, Level AA), advanced synthesizer speech characteristics such as emphasis (1.6.3, Level AAA) and features such as spelling (1.6.3, Level AAA).

notes.content: If browsers provide speech output for mainstream users, they should make the speech configurable enough to be usable by a wide range of individuals. When an add-on adds speech output to the user agent, it becomes part of the user agent, and therefore should meet the requirements of 1.6.

success_criteria.title: Speech Rate, Volume, and Voice
success_criteria.description: If synthesized speech is produced, the user can specify the following:

special_cases.title: Speech volume (independently of other sources of audio)
Voice, when more than one voice is available

success_criteria.title: Speech Pitch and Range
success_criteria.description: If synthesized speech is produced, the user can specify the following if offered by the speech synthesizer:

notes.content: Because the technical implementations of text to speech engines vary (e.g. formant-based synthesis, concatenative synthesis), a specific engine may not support varying pitch or pitch range. A user agent should expose the availability of pitch and pitch range control if the currently selected or installed text to speech engine offers this capability.

special_cases.title: Pitch (average frequency of the speaking voice)

success_criteria.title: Synthesized Speech Features
success_criteria.description: If synthesized speech is produced, the following features are provided:

special_cases.title: "Spell-out"
special_cases.description: text is spelled one character at a time, or according to language-dependent pronunciation rules.

special_cases.title: At least two ways of speaking numerals
special_cases.description: spoken as individual digits and punctuation (e.g. "one two zero three point five" for 1203.5 or "one comma two zero three point five" for 1,203.5), and spoken as full numbers are spoken (e.g. "one thousand, two hundred and three point five" for 1203.5)

special_cases.title: At least two ways of speaking punctuation
special_cases.description: spoken literally, and with punctuation understood from speech characteristics like pauses.

success_criteria.title: Synthesized Speech Language
success_criteria.description: If synthesized speech is produced and more than one language is available, the user can change the language.

success_criteria.title: Advanced Speech Characteristics
success_criteria.description: If synthesized speech is produced, the user can adjust all of the speech characteristics provided by the speech synthesizer.

guidelines.title: Enable configuration of user stylesheets
guidelines.summary: The user agent can disable author stylesheets (1.7.1, Level A) , supports user stylesheets or style mechanism (1.7.2, Level A), the user can choose which if any user-supplied (1.7.3, Level A) stylesheets to use, and the user can save stylesheets (1.7.4, Level AA).

success_criteria.title: Disable Author Stylesheets
success_criteria.description: If the user agent supports a mechanism for author styles, the user can disable the use of author styles on the current page.

success_criteria.title: Support User Stylesheet or User Style Modification Mechanism
success_criteria.description: If the user agent supports a mechanism for author styles, the user agent also provides a mechanism for a user styling to override author styling.

success_criteria.title: Apply User Stylesheets
success_criteria.description: If user styles are supported, then the user can enable or disable user styles for:

special_cases.title: All pages on specified websites, or

success_criteria.title: Save Copies of Stylesheets
success_criteria.description: The user can save copies of the stylesheets referenced by the current page. This allows the user to edit and load the copies as user stylesheets.

guidelines.title: Help users to orient within, and control, windows and viewports
guidelines.summary: The user agent provides programmatic and visual cues to keep the user oriented. These include highlighting the viewport (1.8.1, Level A) and customizing the highlighting attributes (1.8.7, Level AA), keeping the focus within the viewport (1.8.2 & 1.8.6, Level A), resizing the viewport (1.8.8, Level A), providing scrollbars that identify when content is outside the visible region (1.8.3, Level A) and which portion is visible (1.8.4, Level A), changing the size of graphical content with zoom (1.8.5, Level A & 1.8.7, Level A), and restoring the focus and point of regard when the user returns to a previously viewed page (1.8.9, Level AA). The user can specify that all viewports have the same user interface elements (1.8.12, Level AA), if and how new viewports open (1.8.10, Level AA), and whether the new viewport automatically gets focus (1.8.11, Level AA). The user can specify that multi-column text blocks be reflowed into a single column (1.8.13, Level AA), that the user can override absolute layout dimensions (1.8.14, Level AA), and linearize the content (1.8.15, Level AA). The user can mark items in a web page and use shortcuts to navigate back to marked items. (1.8.16, Level AAA).

success_criteria.title: Highlight Viewport
success_criteria.description: The user can have the viewport with the input focus be highlighted.

success_criteria.title: Move Viewport to Selection and Focus
success_criteria.description: When a viewport's selection or input focus changes, the viewport's content moves as necessary to ensure that the new selection or input focus location is at least partially in the visible portion of the viewport.

success_criteria.title: Provide Viewport Scrollbars
success_criteria.description: When the rendered content extends beyond the viewport dimensions, users can have graphical viewports include scrollbars, overriding any values specified by the author.

success_criteria.title: Indicate Viewport Position
success_criteria.description: The user can determine the viewport's position relative to the full extent of the rendered content.

success_criteria.title: Allow Zoom
success_criteria.description: The user can rescale content within top-level graphical viewports as follows:

special_cases.title: Zoom in
special_cases.description: to 500% or more of the default size

special_cases.title: Zoom out
special_cases.description: to 10% or less of the default size, so the content fits within the height or width of the viewport

success_criteria.title: Maintain Point of Regard
success_criteria.description: The point of regard remains visible within the viewport when the viewport is resized, when content is zoomed or scaled, or when content formatting is changed.

notes.content: When the point of regard is larger than the viewport, the user agent keeps visible the beginning of the point of regard according to the current language's reading order (e.g. top-left in English)

success_criteria.title: Customize Viewport Highlighting
success_criteria.description: When highlighting viewports as specified by 1.8.1 Highlight Viewport, the user can customize attributes of the viewport highlighting mechanism (e.g. color and width of borders).

success_criteria.title: Allow Viewport Resize
success_criteria.description: The user can resize viewports within restrictions imposed by the platform, overriding any values specified by the author.

success_criteria.title: Provide Viewport History
success_criteria.description: For user agents that implement a history mechanism for top-level viewports (e.g. "back" button), the user can return to any state in the viewport history that is allowed by the content, including:

notes.content: It is recommended that selection also be restored.

success_criteria.title: Allow Top-Level Viewport Open on Request
success_criteria.description: The user can specify whether author content can open new top-level viewports (e.g. windows or tabs).

success_criteria.title: Allow Top-Level Viewport Focus Control
success_criteria.description: If new top-level viewports (e.g. windows or tabs) are configured to open without explicit user request, the user can specify whether or not top-level viewports take the active keyboard focus when they open.

success_criteria.title: Allow Same User Interface
success_criteria.description: The user can specify that all top-level viewports (e.g. windows or tabs) follow the defined user interface configuration.

success_criteria.title: Multi-Column Text Reflow
success_criteria.description: The user can specify that recognized multi-column text blocks each be reflowed into a single column.

notes.content: Some layouts may become unusable if author-specified layout is overridden. In this case, the user can turn linearization off and try another strategy. It is recommended that user agents provide a convenient way for the user to turn this behavior on and off.

success_criteria.title: Ignore Fixed Unit Dimensions
success_criteria.description: The user can have the user agent override author-specified unit dimensions.

success_criteria.title: Linearize Content
success_criteria.description: The user can have recognized content rendered as a single column, overriding author-specified formatting of columns, tables, and positioning.

notes.content: Some layouts may become unusable if author-specified layout is overridden. In this case, the user can turn linearization off and try another strategy. It is recommended that user agents provide a convenient way for the user to turn this behavior on and off.

success_criteria.title: Provide Web Page Bookmarks
success_criteria.description: The user can mark items in a web page, then use shortcuts to navigate back to marked items. The user can specify whether a navigation mark disappears after a session, or is persistent across sessions.

guidelines.title: Provide alternative views
guidelines.summary: The user can view the source of content (1.9.2, Level AAA), and an outline view of content. (1.9.1, Level AA).

success_criteria.title: Outline View
success_criteria.description: Users can view a navigable outline of the headings in rendered content that allows focus to be moved to the corresponding element in the main viewport.

notes.content: An outline view might also include other named elements such as document landmarks.

success_criteria.title: Source View
success_criteria.description: The user can view all source text that is available to the user agent.

guidelines.title: Provide element information
guidelines.summary: The user can access information about relationships between elements (e.g. form labels, table headers) (1.10.1, Level AA), and extended link information (e.g. title, internal vs. external) (1.10.2, Level AAA)

success_criteria.title: Show Related Elements
success_criteria.description: The user can access the information from explicitly-defined relationships in the content, including at least the following:

special_cases.title: calculated accessible name for controls (e.g. form fields, buttons)
row and column labels for a table cell

success_criteria.title: Show Element Hierarchy
success_criteria.description: The user can determine the path of element nodes going from the root element of the element hierarchy to the currently focused or selected element.

principles.title: Ensure that the user interface is operable

notes.content: Modality Independence: Users interacting with a web browser may do so using one or more input methods including keyboard, mouse, speech, touch, and gesture. It's critical that each user be free to use whatever input method, or combination of methods, works best for a given situation. If every potential user task is made accessible — so multiple modalities are supported — a user can choose what works best. For instance, if a user can't use or doesn't have access to a mouse, but can use and access a keyboard, the keyboard can call a modality independent control to activate an OnMouseOver event. Another example is a user on a mobile device that lacks keyboard who uses uses taps, wirelessly connected devices, and voice commands to simulate discrete or keyboard input. See Independent User Interface: Events for additional information on APIs and techniques for modality independent controls.

guidelines.title: Ensure full keyboard access
guidelines.summary: Every viewport has a keyboard focus (2.1.2, Level A). Users can operate all functions using just the keyboard (2.1.1, Level A), activate important or common features with shortcut keys, (2.1.6, Level A), escape keyboard traps (2.1.3, Level A), specify that selecting an item in a dropdown list or menu not activate that item (2.1.4, Level A) and use standard keys for its platform (2.1.5, Level A).

success_criteria.title: Provide Full Keyboard Functionality
success_criteria.description: All functionality can be operated via the keyboard using sequential or direct keyboard commands that do not require specific timings for individual keystrokes, except where the underlying function requires input that depends on the path of the user's movement and not just the endpoints (e.g. free hand drawing). This does not forbid and should not discourage providing other input methods in addition to keyboard operation including mouse, touch, gesture and speech.

success_criteria.title: Has Keyboard Focus
success_criteria.description: Every viewport has an active or inactive keyboard focus at all times.

success_criteria.title: Avoid Keyboard Traps
success_criteria.description: If keyboard focus can be moved to a component using a keyboard interface (including nested user agents), then focus can be moved away from that component using only a keyboard interface. If this requires more than unmodified arrow or Tab keys (or standard exit methods like Escape), users are advised of the method for moving focus away.

success_criteria.title: Separate Selection from Activation
success_criteria.description: The user can specify that focus and selection can be moved without the user agent or author-supplied content further changing focus, selection, or the state of controls.

success_criteria.title: Follow Text Keyboard Conventions
success_criteria.description: The user agent follows keyboard conventions for the operating environment.

success_criteria.title: Make Keyboard Access Efficient
success_criteria.description: The user agent user interface includes mechanisms to make keyboard access more efficient than sequential keyboard access.
